to the open Telemetry Community if you

slightly different concept a distributed
Trace is really following a request as
it goes from Hop to hop across uh the
different
um
microservices within an application so
with a distributed Trace you typically
have the concept of spans like you click
on something in your browser right that
starts off the top level request that's
your user request behind the scenes
maybe that needs to go to a catalog
service that's going to be a different
span the catalog service might be making
a request to a database it's hopping
over to the database that's another span
and it's just collecting all this
information as the request is making its
way through the system collecting all
that and aggregating it all together and
connecting it all together and that's
what a distributed Trace means
right
um and so this is important because
the state of the art today is that
distributed tracing is hard to do with
ebpf so why is distributed tracing hard
um so to do distributed tracing properly
you need context propagation
right we're about to follow the request
as it goes from Hop to hop across the
different microservices well we need to
know where that request came from and so
typically there's a trace ID in a
request that we need to be able to
follow say the client sends a request a
get request to a service right there's a
trace ID in there somebody had to add
that Trace ID into the HTTP request
right and then it gets into the service
maybe maybe it's like node.js service
maybe there's a lot of different threads
and events going on so maybe it gets put
into a buffer for some time then gets
picked up later and it gets sent a
request to a database again we need to
have the trace ID following that request
all the way through
throughout the code to be able to make
this Association
and so if you take the approach of I

that makes this context propagation
difficult
